Starting day 2 post round 2 after my Nuelasta shot yesterday afternoon. Didn't want to drive that far if I start feeling lousy plus...last minute holiday things to do as well!!  If I haven't said it recently, I just want to remind all of you how grateful I am to have your support through all of this.  Happy Holidays to all and thank you for being such an important part of this journey.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 09:38PM anniebell wrote: Good morning to all and glad to hear that everyone had a pretty good holiday.  I was with my family at my house.  Everyone pretty much picked up the slack and pitched in knowing that I wasn't on top of my game which was wonderful, but I have to admit, it just wasn't the same this year.  I was really tired and crabby. Does anyone emotionally crash after the steroids wear off?    Regarding the side effects...I have been wearing my wig for about 3 weeks but this time my scalp was on fire and I have a rash on the top of my head with little pimples.  It's better today but Saturday was awful. The stubble that I do have left on my head is coming out more so I suspect that the pain was a precursor to it falling out. I too had/have gel nails on before chemo.  The kind that I have don't soak off and I didn't want them to file them off my nails for fear that they would be more weak and brittle so I am just growing them out.  I  have them french manicure style so the nail bed is visible and I did have a schelacque polish put over them.  The chemo team seems to be ok with this.  I haven't had kidney pain but I do get a burning under my right ribs at times.  Wonder if it's gallbladder issues? My appetite was outrageous yesterday!!  I ate everthing that wasn't nailed down.  Salty foods seemed to be the best and sweets. Everything that I know I shouldn't eat but it made me feel better.  Hoping that those who start this week have uneventful treatments and know that the waiting is the worst part.  For those who are post 1 or 2 we are just that much closer to getting off this train.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 07:08PM anniebell wrote: Hi All,  first of all welcome to the new gals.  There is a wealth of support here and I hope you don't hesitate to share any fears or concerns.  It really helps to have this place to express ourselves.  Rachel...hope you had a great birthday and was able to something fun!!.  Heather,  congrats on your new edition.  I wish I could give advice on uploading but that is not my forte.  To everyone else...it sounds like you are holding your own.   This 3rd treatment has been the easiest by far for me.  Just an example of how different our experiences are.  I just need to be sure I get enough sleep.  Of course now I get anxious about what #4 will be like.  My last is Feb1 and I am going to ask if I need to get the Neulasta shot.  My blood work has been fine throughout this process but then again, maybe I shouldn't press my luck. Eyebrows and lashes are sparse but still holding on.   How I found my lump was a bit of devine intervention.  I ran into something with my boob while I was camping with a bunch of girlfriends and at the time grabbed my self and said "that's going to leave a mark" but went on with the fun of the weekend.  About a week later I rolled over in bed and it hurt there so I started poking around and it was lumpy and tender.  I had forgotten that I had run into something until my PCP asked if I had any trauma when I went to see her the next day.  She wasn't all that concerned but said we should check it out just to be safe.  I actually had my mammo the following day at the small rural hospital that I work at.  The tech is also a BC survivor and told me that something didin't look right.  The radiologist spent quite a bit of time going over my US and mammo with me at that time...I'm sure because I was an emplyoyee.  I was pretty prepared to hear the news after my biopsy results were in.  If I hadn't ran into something, I wonder how long it would have been before I would have found it.  I had had a clean mammo 9 months prior but it's ILC and it doesn't show up well on regular mammos.   Bailey...I loved your book story and will be looking for it. I too have had weight gain.  Not sure if it is fluid retention but I doubt it because I continue to have a voracious appetitie.  My taste buds get a little dicey but it doesn't seem to affect what I eat(anything not nailed down!!) I too am emotional and still get anxious about it "being everywhere" I'm hoping my visits with the Onc Psych will help me work through it better than I'm doing on my own.  Maybe she will suggest some meds. I hope everyone has a good week.  Does anyone have a treatment?  I feel like this is an in between week for all of us.    Oh and Heatherweather and anyone else interested,  Headcovers.com has human hair eyebrows that are on a clear silicone base and glue on.  They come in a variety of shapes.  I have them but haven't used them yet.  They look like they would be nice if the eyebrows decide to vacate completely.

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2011 11:31PM anniebell wrote: WaveWhisperer..welcome aboard and we are all so gratefull for this forum to share and compare.  A quick couple of things before I'm off to work.  Whole Foods...excellent idea especially since you won't know for sure how you will be feeling. Side effects...you will have some.  Each one of ours have been a bit different.  All manageable to some degree. Constipation...been there.  Start a high fiber diet now.  I ate Activia greek yougurt daily but still ended up with it.  I used duculax and miralax.  I waited til it was an issue which was a mistake. The Claritin is to help counteract the bone and joint pain if you are getting the Neulasta shot to increase your WBC.  I got the shot but didn't use the Claritin.  Flu like aches and pains for about 36 hours then ok.  MO and I are going to re-evaluate for next time but if I  do get it I am going to try the Claritin.  Wigs...I bought mine on line and it is as close to my original hairstlye as I could imagine.  Just needs a little tweeking so it doesn't too perfect.  I am also pursuing a semi-permanent wig with human hair that stays on for 4-6 weeks at a time and is managed like your own through a local person.  The website I shopped at was wigs.com and they were extremely helpful over the phone when it came to picking a color.  There are a ton of other sites out there as well and all carry about the same styles. You are right...unless they are/have gone through this...they really don't know what it feels like. We are going through this...together!!

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 04:35AM anniebell wrote: Good morning to all.  I'm up at my usual crack of dawn today and still feeling pretty good!!  I do go for my Neulasta shot today and have to admit that I'm anxious about that because of everything that I have been hearing about the aches and pains.  Heather, I'm not sure how it is decided who gets one and who doesn't.  I work in a hospital and when I reminded my Onc. about that he wanted to add it to keep my immune system up. My treatment center is about 30 miles from home but after today they have arranged to have my shot and blood draws given at an affiliated clinic 1 mile from my house. Check to see if that's an option should you need it.  I'm doing it at the infusion clinic today because I also have an appointment to have my tissue expander's filled at the same place...2 birds-1 stone. Also, I don't have a port.  When I asked about it, my Onc. said that for 4 treatments we would  see how I do and add one if necessary.  I also Heather feel your pain about drinking water.  I have to force myself but I do feel that it has helped with the non- existent nausea (and the meds too of course) but so far I haven't even had a inclining of it...knock on wood!  I was warned of constipation as a SE and water will help that too.  I have added Activia Greek yogurt to my regime for it's colon benefits and protein.  I was told that chemo patients need about 75 grams of protein a day so I'm trying to add it where ever I can. I also got some whey protein powder to add to juice. To the other women...Wildrumara and Mercy4all..welcome!! and hope that we can be support and a resource for you! Wildrumara, sounds like maybe you could be our "go to" gal since you are ahead of us.  Both of you, please keep us posted on how your process is going.  Prayers to all...Ann

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 10:07AM anniebell wrote: Wave...I think it can present in different patterns.  My phlebitis was definitely along the vein line. I could feel the chemo burning during my infusion, but I was surprised that it showed up so far out from the treatment.  I had multiple nurses where I work confirm it was phlebitis.  I would continue to do what you are doing but a nurse I work with suggested outlining the reddened area with a Sharpie marker so you can tell if it's spreading or like your nurse said, if it gets hard. I haven't read anything about ILC vs IDC having different treatment approaches nor has my MO made mention of a difference.  I sure am considering emailing him before my TE exchange in 2 weeks to re-confirm no rads. My tumor was along my chest wall and while they got clean margins, they were small margins. The surgeon said that the tumor rolled right off the fascia so she wan't concerned about it rooting down.   Just want to clarify in the hair department that while I do have new growth, I certainly don't have a full head of new growth.  I don't want to disillusion anyone...at this point, however, any hair growth is encouraging!

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 11:04AM anniebell wrote: Hi Everyone...I have to make a better effort to write more often...I had to take notes on what everyone has been posting so that I could remember what I want to say to you. Ok...big chemo brain moment this morning when I set my living rook clock forward 2 hours.  I felt like a boob when I showed up at a friends Arbonne skin care party an hour too early.  By the way,  Arbonne says their products are paraben and sulfate free. Thanks everyone again for the well wishes for my mother.  Her pacemaker is doing it's job keeping her pulse at a healthy range(it was as low a 30 when she went to ER) and her blood pressure normal. I don't have to reschedule my TE exchange although now I am wondering if my starting Arimidex will increase my risk for blood clots.  Sounds like I will be making a call tomorrow just to be safe. Rachel, I'm sorry to hear that today is rough for you.  It sounds like you had a nice time at the concert the other night.  I agree with you about appreciating things differently now. I will be glad to get these TE's out on Tuesday.  I'ts like having bricks on your chest.  I find myself holding back on hugs because they are so hard and un-natural feeling on top of being downright uncomfortable. Robin-WOOT WOOT on the weight loss.  You reminded me to drink more lemon water...thank you for that. I can't give up sugar completely but I have changed my overall eating habits considerably.  I use to cook(on the occasions when I actually did) with the Paula Dean stick of butter protocol.  That recipe is now gone along with fried foods and various other unhealthy meals but I still like chocolate.  I don't like dark chocolate but making myself eat that instead of milk chocolate when I do.  I have lost about 4-5 lbs. of the 10 that I gained during chemo. Karmil,  I hope that sore throat doesn't turn into anything more than that.  I'm ready to ditch the wig too.  I also have the wig hugger band which does make wearing it more comfortable but I was noticing the same thing as you as far as hair not growing in the area.  I don't want to do anything to discourage hair growth at this stage of the game. I'm glad to hear that your daughter hasn't been too heartbroken about the fish.   Ckk...how are you doing?  I still get short of breath with climbing stairs and distance walking almost 6 weeks out from my last chemo but I am slowing getting stronger.  It will come. I will be thinking of you tomorrow and that the BMRI goes well. Wave,  I hope you enjoyed your pedicure.  That was the first thing I did when I knew I was out of the danger zone for infections.  It felt so good.  My feet looked like my mothers after all of this.  Pedicures are a sign of summer!! I admire you for participating in the rads clinical trial.  Kathy,  I'm sorry to hear that you had such a rough week.  You have to do what's right for you.  I don't think you fear is out of line here.  I don't think that I knew you were a teacher.  What grade? Bailey...hearing that your flowers are blooming is so encouraging!! I'm ready for this winter to be done and over(actually I'm ready for BC to be done and over).  It was in the 60's here today and it felt glorious!!  Every fall I say that I'm going to plant tulips and daffodills and then I never do. Sounds like JD is holding his own!! Gracie...did you enjoy your manicure?  It must have been good to hear your doc say that there is a low chance for recurrance on the skin.  Way to go ont he walking.  I intended on doing that today but got a manicure instead!  So far I have not had any hot flashes with the Arimidex in fact I feel cold most of the time.  I am almost 2 weeks into it.  I keep waiting for some sort of SE to hit.  The only thing I notice is my face is breaking out a bit but it may be related to peach fuzz growing back. The puffy eyes have subsided for the most part.  I have been taking antihistamines day and night so it must have been allergy related.  With the crazy winter we had who knows.  Hair update:  I have a dark hue now with a few hairs about and inch long and the remainder soft stubble. It's looking pretty dark with white patches at my temples. Here's to a good week for all

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 07:47PM anniebell wrote: Ok so I can see that I am not doing a good job keeping everyone's schedules straight because I thought that Bailey was doing one today with Heather. My apologies in advance for any further screw ups! Sounds like a few of you guys are having a rough time of things so I am sending huge hugs and prayers that everything simmers down soon.  My mouth feels like a sandpit but it doesn't appear to affect my appetite as I have a voracious one.  I actually crave sauerkraut which is just crazy even though I am from the state of bratwurst and kraut (and beer and cheese LOL!!)  The emotional rollercoster has settled down a bit and I'm feeling better but I get waves of fatigue throughout the day.  I have been working full days but my boss lets me pace myself workload wise for which I am grateful.   I found a study at the NCI center here in Madison that is testing the TC/ Nuelasta combo.  They are giving the TC every 2 weeks versus 3 along with the shot with the rationale that the body rebounds faster with the Neulasta and can tolerate a faster pace.  I don't get my care there due to insurance but I can hardly imagine every 2 weeks of chemo.  At least this way there is a small window of feeling somewhat normal before starting the vicious cycle all over again. On the flip side your are done in 8 weeks instead of 12.   If I had to guess what the culprit is of the spasms it's the Neulasta based on my experience but this time all of the aches and pains have been minimal with the Claritin on board.  To those who are looking for wigs...good luck to you in finding a good match.  That was such a huge source of anxiety for me until I found the one i'm using.  The other day a woman at work who is also a BC survivor asked when I expected to loose my hair.  I gave a big hug and told her she just made my next 6 months!!  So we will get through all of this as those strong warriors before us have and offer hope and support to our followers.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 09:38PM anniebell wrote: Some people do say the most ridiculous things during times like this.  I also get the" that went by fast" or "you are doing so well"  and my all time favorite.."you don't even look like your going through chemo"...REALLY??? now what do you think that people who get chemo are suppose to look like?  I still look like me because it's me going through chemo...UGH!!  I'm pretty straight up with folks and say things back like"it was fast because you're not the one having it" or "looks can be deceiving" and my favorite.. "you haven't seen me bald and naked" I know that people mean well but there have been times when  I just have to roll my eyes.  I do try to lace my responses with sarcasm and humor for their sake but honestly. Does anyone else notice that their filter doesn't work so well right now?  I find myself blurting out exactly what I think before thinking things through.  This is not a new phenomenon for me but I can tell it's more exaggerated now.   On to itchy scalps.   Baily my scalp itched until about 2 weeks after round 2.  My wig drove me nuts and I felt like a monkey at the zoo always sctaching and picking.  I still have a rash along the back of my neck and scalp but over all the iching has gotten better.  I used gold bond powder and lots of lotion.  I also exfoliated the scalp in the shower with a body puff.   Oh I can tell already this morning that I am going to be edgy today...and I'm not even on steroids anymore for an excuse .   To anyone having a treatment today...good luck and prayers to you. I haven't mentioned it for a while but I just want to remind everyone how wonderful you all are and how blessed I feel to have you along side me through this.  XXOO.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 06:01PM anniebell wrote: Mom--Lots of different things in my bloodwork have been off since this has started.  I like you always assume the worse but I also have a medical background so I know just enough to be dangerous to myself.  Lots of things can cause that figure to rise including the Neulasta.  Heck...after my first injection I had a blood draw at the emergency room...bloodwork shows Blasts in my blood.  I figure I have Leukemia....it was the Neulasta.  A vitamin D defeciency which I just found out this week that I have, can be a cause too.  I was going to mention that to all of us "northern" gals to have theirs checked because that lack of sun exposure is the culprit and can add to the already debilitating fatigue. I have taken 2000 iu's 2 days now and feel tons better.   I will stop back this weekend to check in on everyone but I just wanted to put my 2 cents in about the bloodwork issue.  Take care all and hang in there!!

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2011 08:42AM anniebell wrote: HI all...just checking from a very eventful past 30 hours.  Yesterday I develop extreme low back pain with spasms that made child birth seem like a bee sting sending me to the ER.  This has been a semi chronic issue over the years but nothing like what I experienced yesterday.  After good IV meds, the pain subsided but they wanted to do a blood draw (CBC with differential meaning they check the specific cells and structures more than what a straight CBC does).  Test comes back indicating that I have more Blasts in my blood than I should,  This could indicate various forms of Leukemia.  Needless to say in my overmedicated state I was wild with fear and anxiety.  My Onc. did call me this morning to say that this is a perfectly normal response to the Neulasta shot and it was doing what it was suppose to.  Just an FYI if anyone finds themselves in a similar situation. This afternoon the back is much better I am happy to say.  To mercy4all.  Your MO sounds like mine.  Constipation was awful.  I was certain that I was de-boarding this train and not doing it again.  My Oncotype DX score came back at 16(low risk), I had a BMX with clean but small margins no lymph node involvement and no LVI.  My Onc was very in favor of the chemo inspite of this stating that the Adjuvant Online assessment indicated benefits from it and the Oncotype DX was based on older chemo regimes.  This is how I came to terms with doing the chemo.  If the cancer does come back, do I want to saySH--! I should of done the chemo which at that point it's too late or do I want to go SH--!! well at least I did what I could to try to stop it. Ultimately, my doc said I have to do what going to let me sleep at night which I thought was a good piece of advise. I am curious though...why do they think your risk for recurrance is high? Thank you for the warm wishes TifJ!!! and here is to us 1 year from now!!  Robin...I debuted my wig yesterday at work with very nice feedback( at least they were nice enough to say so!)  I will next in line for the shave.  Good for you taking charge!!!  To the other women I hope you are all doing well and as I have mentioned before...thank you for being a part of this ride.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 11:38PM anniebell wrote: Mom...I take 2 doses of steroids (dexamethasone or Decadron) the day before, the day of, and the day after each infusion.  These are in addition to the anti-nausea meds.  The steroids, as I understand, help with the side effects from the chemo such as weight gain/fluid retention and allergic reaction that Taxotere can cause as some of the others have experienced.  They also put it into my chemo pre- med IV.n They also can couse weight gain and a "moon face" appearance but will go away.  My pharmacist told me the dose is low and short so it shouldn't cause any long term effects that steroids can cause.
